paper:
It is argued that to sustain a competitive advantage, Web retailers must align their strategies with the product characteristics and buying practices of customers in their market segment. The dot-com retail market is divided into 4 segments on the basis of the type of good sold, and the strategies needed to succeed in each segment are examined.

I am writing to express my sincere interest in your paper on the strategies required for Web retailers to maintain a competitive advantage by aligning their strategies with the product characteristics and buying practices of customers in their market segment. Your paper's division of the dot-com retail market into four segments based on the type of goods sold, and the subsequent examination of the strategies needed for success in each segment, is particularly captivating. I am eager to delve deeper into the content of your paper, as I believe it will provide valuable insights into the dynamic world of e-commerce.

paper:

The dot-com retail market is divided into 4 segments on the basis of the type of good sold, and the strategies needed to succeed in each segment are examined.

I am extremely interested in your paper which focuses on the alignment of strategies between web retailers and their market segments to maintain a sustainable competitive advantage. paper:
This paper analyzes the problems associated with marketing a durable through leases and sales. Academic research in this area has argued that in a monopolistic environment, leasing dominates selling. Hence, leasing and selling should not co-exist and the firm should concentrate its efforts solely on leasing. We show that the relative profitability of leasing and selling hinges on the rates at which leased and sold units depreciate. In particular, we find that leasing does not dominate selling in all cases; if sold units depreciate at a significantly higher rate than leased units, a monopolistic firm is better off by only selling its product. In addition, we find that if leaded and sold products depreciate at different rates, then the optimal strategy for the firm involves a combination of both leasing and selling. We conclude the paper with an empirical analysis of the depreciation rates of leased and sold units of a popular car model. We find that the depreciation rate of leased cars has been significantly lower than the depreciation rate of sold cars.

I am thrilled to express my interest in your paper discussing the marketing strategies for durable goods through leases and sales. Your analysis delves into the impact of leasing and selling in a monopolistic environment, highlighting the importance of the depreciation rates of leased and sold units. The empirical analysis of a popular car model's depreciation rates further adds credibility to your findings. I am eager to dive deeper into the paper to gain insights into the optimal strategies for firms in managing the marketing of durable goods.

paper:
This study investigates whether individual top executives have incremental effects on their firms’ tax avoidance that cannot be explained by characteristics of the firm. To identify executive effects on firms’ effective tax rates, we construct a data set that tracks the movement of 908 executives across firms over time. Results indicate that individual executives play a significant role in determining the level of tax avoidance that firms undertake. The economic magnitude of the executive effects on tax avoidance is large. Moving between the top and bottom quartiles of executives results in approximately an 11 percent swing in GAAP effective tax rates; thus, executive effects appear to be an important determinant in firms’ tax avoidance.

I am delighted to express my keen interest in your paper that explores the impact of individual top executives on their firms' tax avoidance strategies, beyond the influence of firm characteristics. Your study's unique approach, utilizing a dataset that tracks executive movements across firms over time, provides valuable insights into the significant role played by individual executives in determining firms' tax avoidance levels. The substantial economic magnitude of the executive effects on tax avoidance, resulting in an approximately 11 percent swing in GAAP effective tax rates, underscores the importance of executive decision-making in this realm. I am eager to delve further into your research to understand the intricate dynamics between executives and firms' tax strategies.

paper:
How do firms choose between formal and informal strategies in emerging markets? While the existing literature focuses mostly on the effect of informality on firm outcomes, little research has been conducted on how these firms set strategies in response to their external environment. Using data on routes of minibus taxi operators in South Africa, we explore how the external environment informs this strategic choice. Through spatial and regression analysis, we find that firms choose over a spectrum of informality over time and space in response to demand and availability of public infrastructure. Investigating this phenomenon further through interviews with stakeholders throughout the minibus taxi industry, we find that these firms blend formal and informal strategies to maximize their profit-making potential in the face of insufficient infrastructure and economic and physical uncertainty.

I am extremely excited about your paper that investigates the strategic choices made by firms in emerging markets when determining whether to adopt formal or informal strategies. The dearth of research in this area makes your study all the more intriguing. By analyzing data on minibus taxi operators in South Africa and conducting spatial and regression analysis, you shed light on the influence of the external environment, specifically the demand and availability of public infrastructure, on firms' decision-making processes. The findings that firms employ a spectrum of informality over time and space, and blend formal and informal strategies to navigate economic and physical uncertainty, demonstrate the complexities of strategic choices in emerging markets. I am eager to delve deeper into your study to gain a comprehensive understanding of this dynamic phenomenon.

paper:
Multinational firms (MNEs) accounted for 42 percent of US manufacturing employment, 87 percent of US imports, and 84 of US exports in 2007. Despite their disproportionate share of global trade, MNEs’ input sourcing and final-good production decisions are often studied separately. Using newly merged data on firms’ trade and FDI activity by country, we show that US MNEs are more likely to import not only from the countries in which they have affiliates, but also from other countries within their affiliates’ region. We rationalize these patterns in a unified framework in which firms jointly determine the countries in which to produce final goods, and the countries from which to source inputs. The model generates a new source of scale economies that arises because a firm incurs a country-specific fixed cost that allows all its assembly plants to source inputs from that country. This shared fixed cost across plants creates interdependencies between firms’ assembly and sourcing locations, and leads to non-monotonic responses in third markets to bilateral trade cost changes.

I am highly intrigued by your paper that explores the interconnectedness of multinational firms' (MNEs) input sourcing and final-good production decisions, shedding light on their significant role in US manufacturing employment, imports, and exports. Your use of merged data on firms' trade and Foreign Direct Investment (FDI) activities offers a comprehensive understanding of US MNEs' import patterns, not only from countries where they have affiliates but also from other countries within their affiliates' regions. The unified framework you propose, where firms jointly determine production and sourcing countries, elucidates the interdependencies between assembly and sourcing locations. The identification of shared fixed costs across plants highlights the presence of scale economies, adding a new dimension to the study of these complex decision-making processes. I am eager to delve into your research to gain further insights into the non-monotonic responses in third markets resulting from bilateral trade cost changes.

paper:
This paper uses a simulation approach to investigate how different attribute weighting techniques affect the quality of decisions based on multiattribute value models. The weighting methods considered include equal weighting of all attributes, two methods for using judgments about the rank ordering of weights, and a method for using judgments about the ratios of weights. The question addressed is: How well does each method perform when based on judgments of attribute weights that are unbiased but subject to random error? To address this question, we employ simulation methods. The simulation results indicate that ratio weights were either better than rank order weights (when error in the ratio weights was small or moderate) or tied with them (when error was large). Both ratio weights and rank order weights were substantially superior to the equal weights method in all cases studied. Our findings suggest that it will usually be worth the extra time and effort required to assess ratio weights. In cases where the extra time or effort required is too great, rank order weights will usually give a good approximation to the true weights. Comparisons of the two rank-order weighting methods favored the rank-order-centroid method over the rank-sum method. © 1998 John Wiley & Sons, Ltd.

I am absolutely fascinated by your paper that employs simulation methods to investigate the impact of different attribute weighting techniques on decision quality in multiattribute value models. The comparison of various weighting methods, including equal weighting, rank order weights, and ratio weights, provides valuable insights into their performance when based on judgments subject to random error. The simulation results reveal that both ratio weights and rank order weights outperform the equal weights method, with ratio weights being particularly effective when error in the weights is small or moderate. Additionally, the preference for the rank-order-centroid method over the rank-sum method further enriches the understanding of attribute weighting techniques. I am eager to delve further into your research to gain a more comprehensive understanding of the implications and applications of these findings in decision-making processes.

paper:
This article first examines whether brand exposure elicits automatic behavioral effects as does exposure to social primes. Results support the translation of these effects: participants primed with Apple logos behave more creatively than IBM primed and controls; Disney-primed participants behave more honestly than E!-primed participants and controls. Second, this article investigates the hypothesis that exposure to goal-relevant brands (i.e., those that represent a positively valenced characteristic) elicits behavior that is goal directed in nature. Three experiments demonstrate that the primed behavior showed typical goal-directed qualities, including increased performance postdelay, decreased performance postprogress, and moderation by motivation.

I am immensely interested in your paper that examines the automatic behavioral effects of brand exposure, drawing parallels to the effects of exposure to social primes. The findings showcasing the behavioral differences between participants primed with Apple logos and IBM logos, as well as Disney-primed participants and E!-primed participants, provide compelling evidence of the influence of brand exposure on behavior. Additionally, your investigation into the hypothesis that exposure to goal-relevant brands elicits goal-directed behavior, as supported by three experiments demonstrating typical goal-directed qualities, adds further depth to the understanding of the impact of brands on behavior. I am excited to explore your research further, as it offers valuable insights into the relationship between branding and behavior, contributing to both marketing and consumer behavior fields.

paper:
The idea that extreme trading activity contains information about the future evolution of stock prices is investigated. We find that stocks experiencing unusually high (low) trading volume over a day or a week tend to appreciate (depreciate) over the course of the following month. We argue that this high‐volume return premium is consistent with the idea that shocks in the trading activity of a stock affect its visibility, and in turn the subsequent demand and price for that stock. Return autocorrelations, firm announcements, market risk, and liquidity do not seem to explain our results.

I am deeply fascinated by your paper that explores the relationship between extreme trading activity and the future evolution of stock prices. The finding that stocks with unusually high or low trading volume over a day or a week tend to appreciate or depreciate respectively over the course of the following month provides compelling evidence of the high-volume return premium. The analysis presents a convincing argument that shocks in trading activity impact a stock's visibility, subsequently affecting its demand and price. The examination of various factors, such as return autocorrelations, firm announcements, market risk, and liquidity, further strengthens the robustness of the results. I am excited to delve further into your research to gain a comprehensive understanding of the complex dynamics between trading activity and stock prices.

paper:
Using a unique 10-year panel that includes more than 13,300 expected stock market return probability distributions, we find that executives are severely miscalibrated, producing distributions that are too narrow: realized market returns are within the executives’ 80% confidence intervals only 36% of the time. We show that executives reduce the lower bound of the forecast confidence interval during times of high market uncertainty; however, ex post miscalibration is worst during periods of high uncertainty. We also find that executives who are miscalibrated about the stock market show similar miscalibration regarding their own firms’ prospects. Finally, firms with miscalibrated executives seem to follow more aggressive corporate policies: investing more and using more debt financing.

I am greatly intrigued by your paper that investigates the calibration of executives in producing expected stock market return probability distributions. The finding that executives are severely miscalibrated, with realized market returns falling within their 80% confidence intervals only 36% of the time, highlights the extent of their overconfidence. It is especially interesting to observe that executives tend to reduce the lower bound of the forecast confidence interval during periods of high market uncertainty, although their miscalibration remains pronounced during these times. Furthermore, the link between executive miscalibration and similar miscalibration regarding their own firms' prospects, as well as the association with more aggressive corporate policies such as increased investment and higher debt financing, adds depth to the understanding of the impact of executive behavior on firm decision-making. I am eager to delve deeper into your research to gain a comprehensive understanding of the complex interplay between executive miscalibration, market uncertainty, and firm outcomes.

paper:
During World War II, the US government’s Office of Scientific Research and Development (OSRD) supported one of the largest public investments in applied R&D in US history. Using data on all OSRD-funded invention, we show this shock had a formative impact on the US innovation system, catalyzing technology clusters across the country, with accompanying increases in high-tech entrepreneur-ship and employment. These effects persist until at least the 1970s and appear to be driven by agglomerative forces and endogenous growth. In addition to creating technology clusters, wartime R&D permanently changed the trajectory of overall US innovation in the direction of OSRD-funded technologies.

I am sincerely fascinated by your paper that explores the impact of the US government's Office of Scientific Research and Development (OSRD) and its massive investment in applied R&D during World War II.
